src.pstb.string package

Submodules

src.pstb.string.pstb_string module

String utilities.

Functions:

dict_to_csv_str: Convert a dictionary to a CSV string. dict_to_html_str: Convert a dictionary to an HTML string.

src.pstb.string.pstb_string.dict_to_csv_str(data: list[dict], field_names: list | None = None, column_headers: bool = True, quoting: int = 0, quote_char: str = '"', delimiter: str = ',') → str[source]

Convert a dictionary to a CSV string. You can selected which fields to include in the CSV string by specifying a list of field names. Column headers are included by default.

Parameters:

  • data (list) – List of dictionaries.

  • field_names (list, optional) – List of field names (column headers). Defaults to None.

  • column_headers (bool, optional) – Whether to include column headers. Defaults to True.

  • quoting (int, optional) – Quoting style. Defaults to csv.QUOTE_MINIMAL.

  • quote_char (str, optional) – Quote character. Defaults to ‘”’.

  • delimiter (str, optional) – Delimiter. Defaults to “,”.

Raises:

ValueError – If an invalid quoting style is specified.

Returns:

CSV string.

Return type:

str

src.pstb.string.pstb_string.dict_to_html_str(data: dict | list, indent: int = 2) → str[source]

Convert a dictionary to an HTML string. Keys are displayed in bold. This function is recursive, so it can handle nested dictionaries and lists.

Parameters:

  • data (dict | list) – Dictionary or list.

  • indent (int, optional) – Indentation level, must be between 0 and 8. Defaults to 2.

Raises:

ValueError – If indent is not between 0 and 8.

Returns:

HTML string.

Return type:

str
